raw.author: V. C. Wynne-Edwards
contexts: brought out into the open in a famous book by V. C. Wynne-Edwards
This is because Wynne-Edwards, who has been mainly responsible for promulgating the idea of group selection, did so in the context of a theory of 'population regulation'.
This is where Wynne-Edwards parts company with orthodox evolutionary theorists.
A point that is not emphasized in the writings of Wynne-Edwards, or in Ardrey's popularization of his views, is that there is a large body of agreed facts that are not in dispute.
But even here there is less disagreement than you might think from reading his book.
Wynne-Edwards believes that animals who fight over territory are fighting over a token prize, rather than an actual prize like a bit of food.
Winning a territory is therefore, to Wynne-Edwards, like winning a ticket or licence to breed.
Wynne-Edwards interprets dominance hierarchies in a similar way.
Wynne-Edwards has an altogether more daring interpretation.
Perhaps the most startling of Wynne-Edwards's ideas is that of epideictic behaviour, a word that he coined himself.
For Wynne-Edwards, epideictic behaviour is deliberate massing in crowds to facilitate population estimation.
commentaries: The author references Wynne-Edwards as the figure who explicitly presented the theory of group selection in a well-known book.
The author cites Wynne-Edwards as the promulgator of the group selection theory, specifically in the context of population regulation.
The author identifies Wynne-Edwards as holding a distinct theoretical position on the evolution of altruistic birth-control.
The author references the written works of Wynne-Edwards and notes a specific point of omission within them.
The author suggests that a reader of Wynne-Edwards's book might overestimate the level of disagreement on a specific point.
The author references Wynne-Edwards's theory on territorial behavior as a form of population regulation.
The author explains Wynne-Edwards's interpretation of territory as a breeding license.
The author describes how Wynne-Edwards applies his theory of population regulation to dominance hierarchies.
The author presents Wynne-Edwards's more radical group-selectionist interpretation of social rank and breeding rights.
The author introduces Wynne-Edwards's concept of epideictic behavior as a proposed mechanism for population census.
The author details Wynne-Edwards's specific hypothesis about the function of animal aggregations.

raw.author: Charles Darwin
contexts: The next important link in the argument, one that Darwin himself laid stress on (although he was talking about animals and plants, not molecules) is competition.
Incidentally, this was proved in Darwin's lifetime, and it caused Darwin great worry since in those days it was assumed that heredity was a blending process.
It has been understood ever since Darwin.
But now here is a very interesting point realized by Darwin, and clearly enunciated by Fisher.
He concluded, as had Darwin, that delayed reciprocal altruism can evolve in species that are capable of recognizing and remembering each other as individuals.
commentaries: The author references Darwin's emphasis on competition as a key concept in evolution, extending it to replicator molecules.
The author references Darwin's personal concern about the blending theory of heredity, noting it was a source of worry during his lifetime.
The author references Darwin as the historical origin of the understanding of the evolutionary advantage of parental care.
The author notes that Darwin realized an interesting point about sexual selection.
The author notes that Williams's conclusion aligned with Darwin's earlier ideas on the evolution of delayed reciprocal altruism.

raw.author: J. B. S. Haldane
contexts:
What R. A. Fisher, J.
B. S. Haldane, and especially W. D. Hamilton realized, was that the same applies to other close relations-brothers and sisters, nephews and nieces, close cousins.

Even the great mathematical biologist J.
B. S. Haldane (in a paper of 1955 in which he anticipated Hamilton by postulating the spread of a gene for saving close relatives from drowning) remarked:'... on the two occasions when I have pulled possibly drowning people out of the water (at an infinitesimal risk to myself) I had no time to make such calculations.'
commentaries: The author references Haldane as one of the scientists who realized the genetic basis for altruism among close relatives.
The author cites Haldane's personal anecdote from a 1955 paper to illustrate that animals do not consciously perform the complex calculations of kin selection, but act as if pre-programmed to do so.

goodreads_match.title: The Extended Phenotype
goodreads_match.description: People commonly view evolution as a process of competition between individuals--known as "survival of the fittest"--with the individual representing the "unit of selection." Richard Dawkins offers a controversial reinterpretation of that idea in The Extended Phenotype, now being reissued to coincide with the publication of the second edition of his highly-acclaimed The Selfish Gene. He proposes that we look at evolution as a battle between genes instead of between whole organisms. We can then view Nanges in...

raw.author: W. D. Hamilton
contexts: but was made explicit by W. D. Hamilton and G. C. Williams in the sixties.
The essential concept Maynard Smith introduces is that of the evolutionarily stable strategy, an idea that he traces back to W. D. Hamilton and R. H. MacArthur.

What R. A. Fisher, J.
B. S. Haldane, and especially W. D. Hamilton realized, was that the same applies to other close relations-brothers and sisters, nephews and nieces, close cousins.

His two papers of 1964 are among the most important contributions to social ethology ever written, and I have never been able to understand why they have been so neglected by ethologists (his name does not even appear in the index of two major text-books of ethology, both published in 1970).

goodreads_match.title: The Social Contract: A Personal Inquiry into the Evolutionary Sources of Order and Disorder
goodreads_match.title_without_series: The Social Contract: A Personal Inquiry into the Evolutionary Sources of Order and Disorder
goodreads_match.description:
"Violation of biological command has been the failure of social man. Vertebrates though we may be, we have ignored the law of equal opportunity since civilization's earliest hours. Sexually reproducing beings though we are, we pretend today that the law of inequality does not exist. And enlightened though we may be, while we pursue the unattainable we make impossible the realizable."
In his two previous books, Robert Ardrey exploded a series of philosophical landmines. African Genesis (1961) fundamentally a...

raw.title: On Aggression

contexts: These are claims that could have been made for Lorenz's On Aggression, Ardrey's The Social Contract, and Eibl-Eihesfeldt's Love and Hate.

Indeed Konrad Lorenz, in On Aggression, stresses the restrained and gentlemanly nature of animal fighting.
commentaries: The author references this book as an example of works that address human social behaviors but criticizes them for being fundamentally mistaken in their understanding of evolution.
The author cites Lorenz's book 'On Aggression' as an example where the group selection idea is implicitly used, noting Lorenz's unawareness that it contradicts orthodox Darwinian theory.

The author cites Lorenz's book to present the view that animal aggression is often formal and restrained, a perspective the author then proceeds to question and contextualize within evolutionary theory.

goodreads_match.title: On Aggression
goodreads_match.description: This work has had significant impact on the social and biological sciences and is now a classic point of reference for investigations of behavioral patterns. raw.author: Gregor Mendel
contexts: It was the great achievement of Gregor Mendel to show that hereditary units can be treated in practice as indivisible and independent particles.
Mendel's discovery had already been published, and it could have rescued Darwin, but alas he never knew about it: nobody seems to have read it until years after Darwin and Mendel had both died.
commentaries: The author references Mendel's work as a foundational achievement in genetics, noting his demonstration that hereditary units behave like particles.
The author mentions Mendel's discovery as a potential solution to Darwin's worries, highlighting the historical lack of awareness of Mendel's work during Darwin's time.

raw.author: Sir Ronald Fisher
contexts: one feels that Sir Ronald Fisher, the greatest biologist of the twentieth century, meant much the same thing in 1930 by his 'parental expenditure'
But now here is a very interesting point realized by Darwin, and clearly enunciated by Fisher.
They took the Fisher calculations on optimal sex ratios (which we looked at in the previous chapter) and re-worked them for the special case of the Hymenoptera.
commentaries: The author suggests that Fisher's earlier idea of 'parental expenditure' from 1930 was conceptually similar to Trivers's later concept of Parental Investment.
The author states that Fisher clearly enunciated the point about sexual selection realized by Darwin.
The author mentions Fisher's foundational calculations on optimal sex ratios, which were applied by Trivers and Hare.

raw.author: Trivers and Hare
contexts: Trivers and Hare realized that the workers must try to bias the sex ratio in favour of females.
This is a matter that can be put to the test and that is what Trivers and Hare did, using a large number of species of ants.
commentaries: The author cites Trivers and Hare for their insight into worker behavior regarding sex ratio manipulation in social insects.
The author notes that Trivers and Hare conducted empirical tests on ant species to investigate sex ratio conflicts.

raw.title: Adaptation and Natural Selection
raw.author: G. C. Williams
contexts: In this belief I am heavily influenced by G. C. Williams's great book Adaptation and Natural Selection.
commentaries: The author states that his belief about the level of selection in evolution is heavily influenced by this book.

goodreads_match.title: Adaptation and Natural Selection
goodreads_match.description: Biological evolution is a fact--but the many conflicting theories of evolution remain controversial even today. In 1966, simple Darwinism, which holds that evolution functions primarily at the level of the individual organism, was threatened by opposing concepts such as group selection, a popular idea stating that evolution acts to select entire species rather than individuals. George Williams's famous argument in favor of the Darwinists struck a powerful blow to those in opposing camps. His Adaptation and....

raw.title: Love and Hate: The Natural History of Behavior Patterns
raw.author: Irenäus Eibl-Eibesfeldt
contexts: These are claims that could have been made for Lorenz's On Aggression, Ardrey's The Social Contract, and Eibl-Eihesfeldt's Love and Hate.
commentaries: The author cites this book as part of a group that explores human social behaviors but argues they are flawed due to a misunderstanding of evolutionary principles.

goodreads_match.title: Love and Hate: The Natural History of Behavior Patterns
goodreads_match.description: A foundational work in human ethology by Irenäus Eibl-Eibesfeldt, exploring the biological roots of human social behaviors such as aggression, bonding, and communication through cross-cultural studies.

raw.author: J. Z. Young
contexts: As J. Z. Young has pointed out, the genes have to perform a task analogous to prediction.
commentaries: The author cites J. Z. Young as a source for the idea that genes perform a predictive function.

raw.author: N. Smythe
contexts: The theory was originally foreshadowed by N. Smythe but, pushed to its logical conclusion, it bears the unmistakeable signature of A. Zahavi.
commentaries: The author notes that N. Smythe originally foreshadowed the theory of stotting behavior, which was later developed by A. Zahavi.

raw.author: Parker
contexts: Parker and others showed how this asymmetry might have evolved from an originally isogamous state of affairs.
commentaries: The author references Parker's work on the evolutionary origins of gamete size asymmetry.

raw.author: R. A. Fisher
contexts: The gene's-eye view of Darwinism is implicit in the writings of R. A. Fisher and the other great pioneers of neo-Darwinism in the early thirties

What R. A. Fisher, J.
B. S. Haldane, and especially W. D. Hamilton realized, was that the same applies to other close relations-brothers and sisters, nephews and nieces, close cousins.
The explanation was first offered by R. A. Fisher.
commentaries: The author states that the gene's-eye view is implicitly present in the writings of this scientist and other early neo-Darwinists.
The author references Fisher as one of the scientists who realized the genetic basis for altruism among close relatives.
The author credits Fisher with providing the initial explanation for why the numbers of males and females tend to be equal.
